pages.text: Bookmark for NexT Introduce Bookmark is a plugin that allow the users save their reading position. The users could just click the bookmark icon (like üîñ) in left-top of the page to save the position. And when they visit your blog in the next time, they can continue the last reading position by clicking the bookmark icon from the home page. Installation If you want to use the CDN instead of clone this repo, please jump to the Step 3. Step 1 ‚Üí Go to NexT dir Change dir to NexT directory. There must be layout, source, languages and other directories: 123$ cd themes/next$ lsbower.json _config.yml docs gulpfile.coffee languages layout LICENSE.md package.json README.md scripts source test Step 2 ‚Üí Get module Install module to source/lib directory: 1$ git clone https://github.com/theme-next/theme-next-bookmark.git source/lib/bookmark Step 3 ‚Üí Set it up Enable module in NexT _config.yml file: 1bookmark: true And, if you wants to use the CDN, then need to set: 123vendors: ... bookmark: https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/theme-next/theme-next-bookmark@latest/bookmark.min.js Update 12$ cd themes/next/source/lib/bookmark$ git pull

Linearity system : superposition principleÔºàÂè†Âä†ÂéüÁêÜÔºâ. \(\begin{aligned} &F\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)=F\left(x_{1}\right)+F\left(x_{2}\right) \quad \text { Additivity }\\ &F(a x)=a F(x) \quad \quad \quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\text { Homogeneity }\\ &\text { for scalar } a \text { . } \end{aligned}\) Sufficient conditions for existence of the laplace transformation. \(f(t)\) is a piecewise continuous function; \(f(t)\) is bounded ny an exponential functions. Rational function Initial values & final values of laplacian transform properties. * Final value thereom: Suppose that every pole of \(F(s)\) is either in the open left half plane or at the origin, and that \(F(s)\) has at most a single pole at the origin. Then \(s F(s) \rightarrow L \in \mathbb{R}\) as \(s \rightarrow 0\), and \(\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} f(t)=L\). *Initial value theorem: If \(f\) is bounded on \((0, \infty)\) (or if just \(f(t)=O\left(e^{c t}\right)\) ) and \(\lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}} f(t)\) exists then the initial value theorem says \[ \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} f(t)=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} s F(s) \] Transfer function : the ratio of laplace transform of the output over the laplace transform of the input in linear control system. * Static system, represented by block diagram with constant gain. * Linear time-invariant dynamic systems, represented by a transfer function. posts.text: Gerald Durrell to Lee McGeorge (transcribed from LettersLive). Start form 6'55'' of audio. Now, let me tell you something‚Ä¶ I have seen a thousand sunsets and sunrises, on land where it floods forest and mountains with honey-coloured light, at sea where it rises and sets like a blood orange in a multi-coloured nest of cloud, slipping in and out of the vast ocean. I have seen a thousand moons: harvest moons like gold coins, winter moons as white as ice chips, new moons like baby swans‚Äô feathers. I have seen seas as smooth as if painted, coloured like shot silk or blue as a kingfisher or transparent as glass or black and crumpled with foam, moving ponderously and murderously. I have felt winds straight from the South Pole, bleak and wailing like a lost child; winds as tender and warm as a lover‚Äôs breath; winds that carried the astringent smell of salt and the death of seaweeds; winds that carried the moist rich smell of a forest floor, the smell of a million flowers. Fierce winds that churned and moved the sea like yeast, or winds that made the waters lap at the shore like a kitten. I have known silence: the cold, earthy silence at the bottom of a newly dug well; the implacable stony silence of a deep cave; the hot, drugged midday silence when everything is hypnotized and stilled into silence by the eye of the sun; the silence when great music ends. I have heard summer cicadas cry so that the sound seems stitched into your bones. I have heard tree frogs in an orchestration as complicated as Bach singing in a forest lit by a million emerald fireflies. I have heard the Keas calling over grey glaciers that groaned to themselves like old people as they inched their way to the sea. I have heard the hoarse street vendor cries of the mating Fur seals as they sang to their sleek golden wives, the crisp staccato admonishment of the Rattlesnake, the cobweb squeak of the Bat and the belling roar of the Red deer knee-deep in purple heather. I have heard Wolves baying at a winter‚Äôs moon, Red Howlers making the forest vibrate with their roaring cries. I have heard the squeak, purr and grunt of a hundred multi-coloured reef fishes. I have seen hummingbirds flashing like opals round a tree of scarlet blooms, humming like a top. I have seen flying fish, skittering like quicksilver across the blue waves, drawing silver lines on the surface with their tails. I have seen Spoonbills flying home to roost like a scarlet banner across the sky. I have seen Whales, black as tar, cushioned on a cornflower blue sea, creating a Versailles of fountain with their breath. I have watched butterflies emerge and sit, trembling, while the sun irons their wings smooth. I have watched Tigers, like flames, mating in the long grass. I have been dive-bombed by an angry Raven, black and glossy as the Devil‚Äôs hoof. I have lain in water warm as milk, soft as silk, while around me played a host of Dolphins. I have met a thousand animals and seen a thousand wonderful things‚Ä¶ but ‚Äì All this I did without you. This was my loss. All this I want to do with you. This will be my gain. All this I would gladly have forgone for the sake of one minute of your company, for your laugh, your voice, your eyes, hair, lips, body, and above all for your sweet, ever surprising mind which is an enchanting quarry in which it is my privilege to delve.

posts.title: How to comment on a philosophy text?
posts.excerpt: Classnotes and homework of Methodology of Philosophy(2020 Spring Term): How to comment on a text?
posts.text: Classnotes and homework of Methodology of Philosophy(2020 Spring Term): How to comment on a text? Class notes Commenting means to propose a philosophical interpretation of the text. Discription Describing the content/structure of the short passage we comment on.Before commenting, we should first describe, shortly and accurately, what the text says. To make this description different from paraphrasis, we need to focus on the structure and meaning of the short passage we are commenting on. Example: ‚ÄúThe sun is not sight, but isn‚Äôt it the cause of sight itself and isn‚Äôt it seen by it?‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right.‚Äù ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs say, then, that the sun is what I called the offspring of the good, which the good begot as its analogue. What the good itself is in the intelligible realm, in relation to understanding and intelligible things, the sun is in the visible realm, in relation to sight and visible things.‚Äù Do not write: ‚ÄúFirst Socrates states the difference between the sun and sight: sun is the cause of sight and is seen by it. Then, reminding that the sun is begotten by the good, he sketches the analogy between the sun in the visible world and the good in the intelligible world.‚Äù Write instead: ‚ÄúThe analogy between the sun and the good is proposed on the basis of two triple distinctions: the causes of sight and of knowledge (the sun and the good, respectively), the object of sight or knowledge (visible things and, as we learn later, the forms), and the part of ourselves that sees or knows (the eye, and as we later, the soul). These levels are connected together by processes: sight (for the eye) and understanding (for the soul).‚Äù In the latter example, the description of the content of the text never simply repeats the text, but instead takes some distance from the order in which the text presents the information, to better synthetize the philosophical meaning of these few lines. Commenting on a short passage Commenting means making it clear what is the philosophical meaning of the text, by explaining how the meaning unfolds in the text, and its implications. In general, you can comment on several different levels: the words, the grammar/ syntax, and the argument. Commenting on a word means explaining or defining a concept. E.g., defining "Intelligible realm." You can also use etymology if you know it. Commenting on grammar/syntax means to explain how the text suggests effects of meaning that are philosophically relevant, by means of the arrangement of ideas in the sentence. In this extract, you could for instance comment on the parallelism in grammar of: ‚ÄúWhat the good itself is in the intelligible realm, in relation to understanding and intelligible things, the sun is in the visible realm, in relation to sight and visible things.‚Äù Example of commentary on this sentence: ‚ÄúThe very structure of this sentence elaborates on the parallel between the depiction of the visible world and that of the intelligible world: by means of grammar, Plato clearly suggests not only that the good and the sun play the same role in their respective world, but also that the structure of the relationships in which they are involved, in their respective world, with the objects of sight and knowledge are the same. The analogy is indeed by definition not a comparison between elements of a relationship, but a comparison of relationships.‚Äù Commenting on the structure of the argument: this means drawing a hierarchy between the elements of an arguments, as elaborated on the text. Concretely, you should make it clear what is the status of each element of an argument in the whole argument. For instance, mayebe the first couple of sentences in a text express the problem that the author is addressing; the next sentence the solution he is proposing; then, the reason why this is a convinving solution; finally, examples. In the short passage under study here, you could for instance stress that the organization of the cues of Socrates shows that the most fundamental idea, which is expressed first, is that the sun and good are the causes and potential obejcts of sight and knowledge. That, after Glaucon‚Äôs approval of this idea, Plato explains the details of the analogy, but that he adds relevant dimensions progressively, when they are needed for his argument (the idea that sight cannot see by night, for instance, is added later in the text). Techniques to comment on a short passage: In general, the commentary can rely on several techniques: Find examples to make your understanding of the text clearer to your reader. Draw sketchs, compose tables. Note however that a sketch or a table needs itself to be commented on in a sentence or two, to make your point clear. Provide definition, use etymology. Comment on the grammar, on the syntax. Example of commentary Text: ‚ÄúThe sun is not sight, but isn‚Äôt it the cause of sight itself and isn‚Äôt it seen by it?‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right.‚Äù ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs say, then, that the sun is what I called the offspring of the good, which the good begot as its analogue. What the good itself is in the intelligible realm, in relation to understanding and intelligible things, the sun is in the visible realm, in relation to sight and visible things.‚Äù Commentary: The analogy between the sun and the good is proposed on the basis of two triple distinctions: the causes of sight and of knowledge (the sun and the good, respectively), the object of sight or knowledge (visible things and, as we learn later, the forms), and the part of ourselves that sees or knows (the eye, and as we later, the soul). These levels are connected together by processes: sight (for the eye) and understanding (for the soul). The organization of the cues of Socrates shows that the most fundamental idea, which is expressed first, is that the sun and good are the causes and potential objects of sight and knowledge. This idea is the most fundamental one also for the whole text, insofar as it gives the direction to the whole analogy, and also prepares the identity of degree between ontology and epistemology, which Socrates phrases later in the text. After Glaucon‚Äôs approval of this view, Plato explains the details of the analogy. He will add relevant dimensions progressively, when they are needed for his argument (the idea that sight cannot see by night, for instance, is added later in the text). The first sentence in this passage stresses the analogical relationship between the sun and the good. By ‚Äúoffspring of the good,‚Äù Socrates refers to a notion that was introduced just before our passage: in Plato‚Äôs theory of the intelligible and perceptible worlds, the latter is created by the former. The ‚Äúgood‚Äù thus refers to the form of the good. The very structure of the last sentence, where the details of the analogy are explained, elaborates on the parallel between the depiction of the visible world and that of the intelligible world: ‚ÄúWhat the good itself is in the intelligible realm, in relation to understanding and intelligible things, the sun is in the visible realm, in relation to sight and visible things.‚Äù By means of grammar, Plato clearly suggests not only that the good and the sun play the same role in their respective world, but also that the structure of the relationships in which they are involved, in their respective world, with the objects of sight and knowledge are the same. The analogy is indeed by definition not a comparison between elements of a relationship, but a comparison of relationships, as we could represent in this sketch: As an analogy is a comparison of relationships, the point of Plato‚Äôs comparison here is to show the necessity to suppose a form that makes knowledge (or: understanding) of other forms possible. The analogy has not only a descriptive function, but also a persuasive role in the argument: it is obvious that light is necessary to sight, but it is less clear that the good is necesary to knowledge of the others forms. The analogy is, here, dissymmetrical, because Plato suggests that this similitude in relationships between the two worlds is caused by the fact that the good begot the sun; in this sense, the sensible world is a reflection of the intelligible world. Homework: A commentary on Plato, Republic, VII, 517d‚Äì518d. Text: ‚Äì But our present discussion, on the other hand, shows that the power to learn is present in everyone's soul and that the instrument with which each learns is like an eye that cannot be turned around from darkness to light without turning the whole body. This instrument cannot be turned around from that which is coming into being without turning the whole soul until it is able to study that which is and the brightest thing that is, namely, the one we call the good. Isn't that right? ‚Äì Yes. ‚Äì Then education is the craft concerned with doing this very thing, this turning around, and with how the soul can most easily and effectively be made to do it. It isn‚Äôt the craft of putting sight into the soul. Education takes for granted that sight is there but that it isn't turned the right way or looking where it ought to look, and it tries to redirect it appropriately. Socrates tries to illustrate the effect of education through the analogy between sun and the fire in a cavelike dwelling, as we could represent in this sketch: Education doesn't provide knowledge to the soul like putting sight into the blind, but a craft directing the right way to the good. Everyone has the potential to learn, but they are always obsessed with the evil of human life. With the help of education, they can look at divine things in a just way. The first sentence disputes the declaration that education puts new knowledge into souls due to an understatement of education's function. With an analogy between knowledge and sight, Socrates tells us education is an instrument to turn the whole soul into the direction to face the source of light - the good, not just provides sight to eyes, which only involved part of the whole body. After Glaucon's agreement with this claim, Socrates stresses the function of education as a craft to turn us in an appropriate way while we have already know how to use our eyes but not in a right way. A right way to look around means we can learn the knowledge with a most easy and effective move - turning around - namely, education. Craft(techn√™): Plato develops a complex account of techn√™. First of all, a craft has a function (ergon); Through the metaphor of fettered human living in a cave, Socrates hints we are always trapped in the reflection of the real world without realizing what's literally happening in the actual world. Education doesn't mean there's a prophet describing the landscape of the real word to us, but demonstrates us how to achieve the real world and explore it by our own eyes. The shadow of real world also signifies a limitation of the method we are born with to obtain the knowledge while there's a wilder intelligible wolrd we cannot experience due to the less effective way we look at it. Education provides us a way directly - just as easily as turning around, which is not only a effective method but also in a best sense. The essential point of education is not about the range of knowledge, but the awareness of the brightest thing - the good. The shadow projected on the screen can be classified as knowledge, but with a direction aganist the fire, as an analogy of the good. Without an appropriate goal to chase, we can never understand the whole world we are living in. Socrate clarifies the function of education as a craft to lead the whole soul to the good with the comparison between putting sight into blind eyes and turning the object of sight from projected shadow of the real world to the world itself. The goal of education is to explore the intelligible world, not pour the static knowledge of intelligible world into limited souls.

posts.text: Classnotes and homework of Methodology of Philosophy(2020 Spring Term): An overview of scholarship of the problem 'what is the unhypothetical principle in Plato's Republic?' Class notes An overview of scholarship of the problem 'what is the unhypothetical principle in Plato's Republic?' Guideline Views according to which the good is the unhypothetical principle. [Adam 1902; Mason] It means that the form and/or its instanciations are good. Individual forms (justice, beauty‚Ä¶) are good Instanciations of the forms (a just soul, a beautiful city) are good Both instanciations of the forms and individual forms are good. LIMITS: stated by Mason, with this and this and this argument. The unhypothetical principle is said of the forms not individually but as a system The good is this system (LIMITS: stated by Mason, with this and this and this argument.) The good is an property of this system. (LIMITS: you can include here your own idea about the limits of these views.) LIMITS : stated by Baltzly. Views according to which the unhypothetical principle is something else [Baltzly] => the unhypothetical principle is a statement that we cannot reject, else we refute ourselves LIMITS: you can include here your own criticism of the limits of Baltzly's hypothesis. Homework (Baltzly part) One suggestion is that an unhypothetical starting point is a proposition that is established by showing that its denial is self-refuting in a certain sense (Baltzly 1996 1 , 1999;. criticized in Bailey 2006). The first strategy that identifies dialectic's unhypothetical first principle with the good is ontological and equates the unhypothetical aspect of the arche in dialectic with the ontological supremacy of the form of the good (R. 509b6-10). The second strategy is epistemological and treats the unhypothetical character of the dialectician's arche as a matter of the kind of argument used to establish it. According to Baltzly, we obtain two different interpretations of the unhypothetical first principle form perspectives of ontology and epistemology, respectively. If we consider the unhypothetical first principle as the form of the good, we have to assume that dialetic's end point is also its unhypothetical starting point because Plato compares dialectic to a journey towards the grasp of the good itself. (R.532a-b) Tracing back to the Republic, dialectic treats hypotheses as stepping stones to ascend to an unhypothetical starting point of everything, and grasps this principle to come down to a conclusion, which implies that dialectic's end point is a "conclusion". (511b-c) We can demonstrate the argument in this sketch: Apparently, this sketch is not compatible with the content of the good, which includes justice and beauty instead of tons of conclusions. Maybe Baltzly makes a mistake here for considering the journey of dialectic towards the good as the whole process of dialectic, while Plato refers to the first phase of dialectic from hypotheses to the first principle of everything. Therefore, the limitations of assuming the first principle as the good doesn't exit, and this ontology interpretation is reasonable. If we consider the unhypothetical first principle as a method setting a foundation for dialectic to turn the unquestioned hypotheses of mathematics into knowledge (R. 533b6-c5), the unhypothetical first principle is an argument that we cannot reject unless we refute ourselves. (Parmenides. 143b-4a) But this statement supposes an epistemological use of unhypothetical first principle globally, while Plato puts it in the middle of the Republic. Apart from the position of this statement in the whole book, assuming the first principle as a method eliminates the significance and specificity of this principle as unhypothetical and involving everything. We have lots of methods to turn unquestioned hypotheses into knowledge, but dialectic is important because the first phase of it is grasping the good, namely, the brightest thing as a sun. We can consider the unhypothetical first principle as a method, but we cannot discard the property dialectic involved, which is the role of the good. References Baltzly, Dirk C. "To an Unhypothetical First Principle" in Plato's" Republic." History of Philosophy Quarterly (1996): 149-165.‚Ü©Ô∏é

AWL‚Ä≤-t∆èr EE‚Ä≤-g≈ç Merriam-Webster's Vocabulary Builder Quiz 1-1 BENE - well BENE is Latin for ‚Äúwell.‚Äù benediction : A prayer that asks for God's blessing, especially a prayer that concludes a worship service. The moment the bishop had finished his benediction, she squeezed quickly out of her row and darted out the cathedral's side entrance. Dictio is Latin for ‚Äúspeaking.‚Äù Benediction 's meaning becomes something like ‚Äúwell-wishing.‚Äù benefactor : Someone who helps another person or group, especially by giving money. An anonymous benefactor had given $15 million to establish an ecological institute at the university. beneficiary : A person or organization that benefits or is expected to benefit from something, especially one that receives money or property when someone dies. Living in a trailer in near-poverty, she received word in the mail that her father had died, naming her as the sole beneficiary of his life-insurance policy. benevolence : Kindness, generosity. In those financially desperate years, the young couple was saved only by the benevolence of her elderly great-uncle. AM - to love AM comes from the Latin amare, ‚Äúto love.‚Äù amicable : Friendly, peaceful. Their relations with their in-laws were generally amicable, despite some bickering during the holidays. enamored : Charmed or fascinated; inflamed with love. Rebecca quickly became enamored of the town's rustic surroundings, its slow pace, and its eccentric characters. amorous : Having or showing strong feelings of attraction or love. It turned out that the amorous Congressman had gotten his girlfriend a good job and was paying for her apartment. paramour : A lover, often secret, not allowed by law or custom. He had been coming to the house for two years before her brothers realized that he was actually the paramour of their shy and withdrawn sister. Quiz 1-2 BELL - war BELL comes from the Latin word meaning ‚Äúwar.‚Äù antebellum : Existing before a war, especially before the American Civil War (1861‚Äì65). When World War I was over, the French nobility found it impossible to return to their extravagant antebellum way of life. bellicose : Warlike, aggressive, quarrelsome. The more bellicose party always got elected whenever there was tension along the border and the public believed that military action would lead to security. belligerence : Aggressiveness, combativeness. The belligerence in Turner's voice told them that the warning was a serious threat. rebellion : Open defiance and opposition, sometimes armed, to a person or thing in authority. A student rebellion that afternoon in Room 13 resulted in the new substitute teacher racing out of the building in tears. PAC - agree PAC is related to the Latin words for ‚Äúagree‚Äù and ‚Äúpeace.‚Äù pacify : (1) To soothe anger or agitation. (2) To subdue by armed action. It took the police hours to pacify the angry demonstrators. pacifist : A person opposed to war or violence, especially someone who refuses to bear arms or to fight, on moral or religious grounds. Her grandfather had fought in the Marines in World War II, but in his later years he had become almost a pacifist, opposing every war for one reason or another. pact : An agreement between two or more people or groups; a treaty or formal agreement between nations to deal with a problem or to resolve a dispute. The girls made a pact never to reveal what had happened on that terrifying night in the abandoned house. pace : Contrary to the opinion of. She had only three husbands, pace some Hollywood historians who claim she had as many as six. Quiz 1-3 CRIM - fault CRIM comes from the Latin words for ‚Äúfault or crime‚Äù or ‚Äúaccusation.‚Äù criminology : The study of crime, criminals, law enforcement, and punishment. His growing interest in criminology led him to become a probation officer. decriminalize : To remove or reduce the criminal status of. An angry debate over decriminalizing doctor-assisted suicide raged all day in the statehouse. incriminate : To show evidence of involvement in a crime or a fault. The muddy tracks leading to and from the cookie jar were enough to incriminate them. recrimination : (1) An accusation in answer to an accusation made against oneself. (2) The making of such an accusation. * Their failure to find help led to endless and pointless recriminations over responsibility for the accident. PROB - prove PROB comes from the Latin words for ‚Äúprove or proof‚Äù and ‚Äúhonesty or integrity.‚Äù approbation : A formal or official act of approving; praise, usually given with pleasure or enthusiasm. The senate signaled its approbation of the new plan by voting for it unanimously. probate : The process of proving in court that the will of someone who has died is valid, and of administering the estate of a dead person. When her father died, she thought she would be able to avoid probate, but she wasn't that lucky. probity : Absolute honesty and uprightness. Her unquestioned probity helped win her the respect of her fellow judges. reprobate : A person of thoroughly bad character. His wife finally left him, claiming he was a reprobate who would disappear for weeks at a time, gambling and drinking away all his money.

posts.text: Êú¨ÁØáÊñáÁ´†ÊòØÂØπÊØï‰∏öËÆ∫ÊñáÊâ©ÂÖÖÈÉ®ÂàÜ‰∏≠Á¶èÂ§öÂØπÊÑèÂêëÂÆûÂú®ËÆ∫ÁöÑÁª¥Êä§ÁöÑÊ¢≥ÁêÜ‰∏éÊÄùËÄÉ„ÄÇ Á¶èÂ§öÂØπÊÑèÂêëÂÆûÂú®ËÆ∫ÁöÑÁª¥Êä§ Much of Fodor‚Äôs work is devoted to defending intentional realism against such views as they have arisen in both philosophy and psychology. In addition to defending intentional realism against: the behaviorism of Skinner and Ryle ( Fodor 1968 1, 1975 2, Fodor et al. 1974 3 ); the threat of epiphenomenalism ( Fodor 1989 4 ); Wittgenstein and other defenders of the ‚Äúprivate language argument‚Äù ( Fodor and Chihara 1965 5, Fodor 1975 6 ); the eliminativism of the Churchlands ( Fodor 1987 7, 1990 8 ); the instrumentalism of Dennett ( Fodor 1981a 9, Fodor and Lepore 199210 ); the interpretationism of Davidson ( Fodor 1990 11, Fodor and Lepore 1992 12, Fodor 2004 13 ); certain versions of connectionism ( Fodor and Pylyshyn 1988 14, Fodor 1998b 15, chs. 9 and 10 ). 16 ÂØπÊñØÁ∫≥ÈáëÂíåËµñÂ∞îÁ≠âË°å‰∏∫‰∏ª‰πâÁöÑÂõûÂ∫î Why Paramecia Don't Have Mental Representations Êú¨ÁØáÊñáÁ´†Âç≥ÊòØÂØπ‰ΩéÁ≠âÁîüÁâ©ÊòØÂê¶ÂÖ∑ÊúâÊÑèÂêëÊÄßËß£ÈáäËøô‰∏ÄÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑÂõûÂ∫î„ÄÇ Psychological theories purport to explain behavior by reference to the causal properties of mental states, but whereas behaving-at least in the sense of producing adaptive movements-is a pervasive achievement at all levels of the phylogenetic continuum, possessing mental states is presumably not. One might suppose, in particular, that the bag of tricks associated with the Representational Theory of Mind (hereinafter RTM) ought properly to be reserved for application to animals pretty much like us. It would, for example, be preposterous to attribute mental representations to paramecia; where would they keep them? Yet paramecia are negatively phototropic, and tropisms are arguably behaviors in good standing. So, if our behaviors are to be explained by appeal to mental causes, why shouldn 't theirs be? (P3) Êàë‰ª¨Âà©Áî®ÂøÉÁêÜÁä∂ÊÄÅÁöÑÂõ†ÊûúÊïàÂäõËß£Èáä‰∫∫ÁöÑË°å‰∏∫ÔºåÈÇ£‰πà‰ΩéÁ≠âÂä®Áâ©ÊòØÂê¶ÂÖ∑ÊúâÂøÉÁêÜË°®ÂæÅÊù•Ëß£ÈáäÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÁöÑË°å‰∏∫Ôºü‰ΩéÁ≠âÂä®Áâ©‰∏ç‰ºöÊåâÁÖß‰∫∫Á±ªÁöÑ‰ø°Âøµ‰∏éÊÑèÊÑø‰ΩúÂá∫Áõ∏Â∫îÁöÑÁâ©ÁêÜË°å‰∏∫„ÄÇË°å‰∏∫Â≠¶ÂÆ∂ÊúüÊúõ‰∏¢ÂºÉÊÑèÂêëÊÄßËß£ÈáäÁöÑÂéüÂõ†Âç≥Âú®‰∫éÊ≠§ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂØπ‰ΩéÁ≠âÂä®Áâ©ÁöÑÊÑèÂêëÊÄßËß£ÈáäÁ≠â‰∫éÊòØÂú®Êó†‰∏≠ÁîüÊúâ„ÄÇ The point is that it's not just RTM but the whole apparatus of intentional ascription that Dennett's argument puts in jeopardy. The slippery slope objection is one that all intentionalists in psychology must take equally seriously. The second point is that, as Dennett sees, it's not just very small organisms that we have to worry about. Much the same slippery slope argument that gets you from us to paramecia can also be made to get you from computers to thermostats or, for that matter, from us to thermostats.
